Silvija Lazanin 2025/01/30 Can you name a popular mobile game with zero social features? Tough task, right? That‚Äôs because social features in mobile games have gone from being just an option to a must-have strategy for boosting player engagement. There is a wide range of social features you can include in your game, depending on the genre, player preferences, and your goals. Let‚Äôs discuss their importance and explore all the different forms they can take. Growing Importance of Social Features in Mobile Games Back in the day, social features were almost exclusive to mid-core games such as shooters and strategy games. However, over time, these features became standard across genres‚Äîfrom casual to puzzle games. While having a guild or PvP feature in a casual game would have been quite weird 7 years ago, today, it‚Äôs a completely normal thing. According to data.ai, today, ‚Öî of top mobile games have at least one social feature. What changed? Nowadays, players expect connection and community features in games, no matter what type of game they are playing. The pandemic also played a role here, as many people turned to games for social interaction during isolation periods. Moreover, with the rise of UA costs, developers are increasingly focused on engaging and retaining players. Impact and Player Preferences Social features in mobile games are a powerful tool for boosting player retention, monetization, and community building. Being social in a game can give players extra reasons to stay active for longer. While some players simply enjoy being a part of a group, others are motivated by competing with others. Just like in everyday life, there are players who are more and less social. Some players are true social butterflies. These are player personas who consider social features essential to their gaming experience and seek games that allow them to communicate, team up, or play against others. They tend to enjoy genres like MOBA and MMORPG games with features like clans, guilds, teams, PvP modes, chat, etc. On the other hand, some players enjoy occasional social interactions without the pressure of constant engagement. Such players often prefer genres like puzzle and casual strategy games. Common Social Features in Mobile Games Which social features can you include in your game? Here are some of your options‚Äîlet‚Äôs go over the most common and trending social features in mobile games. Social Media Integration Social media integration in 8 Ball Pool Whether you install a simulation, sports, strategy game or else‚Äîyou‚Äôll probably find a social media integration feature. By logging in with social media (e.g., Google or Facebook), players unlock a set of social features such as sharing achievements and inviting friends to the game. Oftentimes, players need a little push to do this. To encourage social media connections, games often reward players with a generous amount of currency for linking their accounts. After all, people put a great deal of trust in friend recommendations, creating a powerful strategy for organic growth. Chat Don‚Äôt want players leaving your game to communicate? Give them an in-game chat platform. Chat features are particularly popular in mid-core games like shooters, RPGs, and strategy games where players need to coordinate and strategize in real-time. The most common form of in-game chat is text chat, where players can send text messages, emojis, but also premade phrases for faster communication. In certain genres like MOBAs and multiplayer RPGs, it‚Äôs also common to have voice chats for direct communication, which allows players to react instantly. For example, the mobile version of the popular shooter game Call of Duty allows players to communicate with teammates during matches via both voice and text chat. Leaderboards Country-wide and friend list leaderboards in Subway Surfers The leaderboard is one of the most popular social features in mobile games, and you can find it in almost every genre. Leaderboards rank players based on their performance compared to others. For example, players can check how they stand against the rest of the world, their country, or people from their friends list. This feature is particularly effective among competitive players, motivating them to perform better, climb the ladder, and get the recognition they strive for. Co-Op and PvP Modes Does your game attract players who like to play in teams or compete? Then consider adding a co-op mode to engage players who prefer to work together towards a common goal.
